STATE OF MICHIGAN
DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
GRETCHEN WHITMER
LANS ING
ELIZABETH HERTEL
GOVERNOR DIRECTOR
May 19, 2023
Sylvia Blythe
Mission Ranch
9300 Lahring Road,
Gaines, MI, 48436
Re: License #: CI250410439
Dear Sylvia Blythe:
Attached is the Renewal Inspection Report for the above referenced agency completed
on . Due to the violations of applicable licensing rules, a written corrective action plan is
required. The corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and must
include the following:
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result
in compliance.
• How compliance with each citation will be achieved.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the action steps in the
corrective action plan.
• Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you fail to submit an acceptable corrective action plan, disciplinary action may result.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager at (616) 204-6992.

Sincerely,
Cassandra Thomas,
Licensing Consultant
enclosure

DIVISION OF CHILD WELFARE LICENSING

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
The agency is in compliance with all applicable rules and statutes except for the
following:
CCI Rule 400.4112 Criminal history check, subject to requirements;
staff qualifications.
(1) Child caring institutions subject to 42 USC 671 shall
not permit a child caring institution staff member to
begin working unless all of the following has been
completed using the forms, and in the manner,
prescribed by the department:
(a) A criminal record check as referenced in R
400.4113(f), including a fingerprintbased check of
national crime information databases, unless an

alternative criminal history check has been approved
by the federal government.
Four of twelve employee files reviewed included documentation that the criminal
history check was completed after the date of hire.
CCI Rule 400.4112 Criminal history check, subject to requirements;
staff qualifications.
(1) Child caring institutions subject to 42 USC 671 shall
not permit a child caring institution staff member to
begin working unless all of the following has been
completed using the forms, and in the manner,
prescribed by the department:
(b) A check of Michigan’s child abuse and neglect
central registry or Canadian provincial agency as
referenced in R 400.4113(i).
Seven of twelve employee files reviewed failed to document a check of
Michigan’s child abuse and neglect central registry or Canadian provincial agency
prior to the start of employment.
CCI Rule 400.4112 Criminal history check, subject to requirements;
staff qualifications.
(1) Child caring institutions subject to 42 USC 671 shall
not permit a child caring institution staff member to
begin working unless all of the following has been
completed using the forms, and in the manner,
prescribed by the department:
(c) A check of other states’ child abuse registry where
the person has lived in within the preceding five years.
Five of twelve employee files reviewed failed to document that the employee had
not resided outside of the state within the last five years and whether or not child
abuse registry clearance had been completed.
CCI Rule 400.4113 Employee records.
An institution shall maintain employee records for each
employee and shall include documentation of all of the
following information prior to employment or at the time
specified in this rule:
(c) Verification of high school diploma or GED when
s pecified by rule.

Two of twelve employee files reviewed had no verification of a high school
diploma or GED.
CCI Rule 400.4113 Employee records.
An institution shall maintain employee records for each
employee and shall include documentation of all of the
following information prior to employment or at the time
specified in this rule:
(d) Work history.
Two of twelve employee files reviewed failed to include documentation of work
history for the employee.
CCI Rule 400.4113 Employee records.
An institution shall maintain employee records for each
employee and shall include documentation of all of the
following information prior to employment or at the time
specified in this rule:
(e) Three dated references which are obtained prior to
employment from persons unrelated to the employee
and which are less than 12 months old.
Seven of twelve employee files reviewed did not include documentation or
verification that three unrelated and dated references had been obtained prior to
employment for the employee.
CCI Rule 400.4113 Employee records.
An institution shall maintain employee records for each
employee and shall include documentation of all of the
following information prior to employment or at the time
specified in this rule:
(i) Documentation from the Michigan department of
human services, the equivalent state or Canadian
provincial agency, or equivalent agency in the country
where the person usually resides, that the person has
not been determined to be a perpetrator of child abuse
or child neglect. The documentation shall be completed
not more than 30 days prior to the start of employment
and every 12 months thereafter.
Three of twelve employee files reviewed failed to document completion of an
annual child abuse and neglect clearance.

CCI Rule 400.4112 Employee records.
An institution shall maintain employee records for each
employee and shall include documentation of all of the
following information prior to employment or at the time
specified in this rule:
(j) A written evaluation of the employee’s performance
within 30 days of the completion of the probationary
period or within 180 days, whichever is less, and a
written evaluation of the employee’s performance
annually thereafter.
Six of twelve employee files reviewed did not have documentation of completed
performance evaluation within 30 days for probationary or 180 days, whichever is
l ess or within one year for other employees.
CCI Rule 400.4114 Tuberculosis screening for employees and
volunteers.
The licensee shall document, prior to employment, that
each employee and volunteer who has contact with
residents 4 or more hours per week for more than 2
consecutive weeks is free from communicable
tuberculosis. Freedom from communicable tuberculosis
shall be verified within the 1 year period before
employment and shall be verified every 1 year after the
last verification or prior to the expiration of the current
verification.
Six of twelve employee files reviewed failed to document that prior to
employment, each employee and volunteer who has contact with youth 4 or more
hours per week for more than 2 consecutive weeks is free from communicable
tuberculosis.
CCI Rule 400.4121 Direct care worker; qualifications.
A direct care worker shall have completed high school
or obtained a general equivalency diploma (GED).
Two of twelve employee files failed to include documentation of high schoolol
completion or that they obtained a general equivalency diploma.

CCI Rule 400.4128 Initial staff orientation and ongoing staff training.
The licensee shall provide an orientation program for
new employees. Job shadowing shall not be the only
form of orientation. The orientation shall include the
following:
(a) The institution’s purpose, policies, and procedures,
including discipline, crisis intervention techniques,
and emergency and safety procedures.
Four of twelve employee files reviewed failed to document completion of
an orientation program consistent with policy requirements.
CCI Rule 400.4128 Initial staff orientation and ongoing staff training.
(4) Training opportunities for direct care staff shall
include, but are not limited to, all of the following:
(h) First aid.
Two of twelve employee files reviewed failed to include documentation of first
aid training for direct care staff.
CCI Rule 400.4166 D ischarge plan.
(1) When a resident is discharged from institutional care,
all of the following information shall be documented in
the case record within 14 days after discharge:
(c) An assessment of the resident’s needs that remain to
be met.
One of one closed case file reviewed failed to include documentation of an
a ssessment of the youth’s needs that remain to be met in the discharge plan.
CCI Rule 400.4166 Discharge plan.
(1) When a resident is discharged from institutional
care, all of the following information shall be
documented in the case record within 14 days after
discharge:
(d) Any services that will be provided by the facility after
discharge.

One of one closed case file reviewed failed to document any services that will be
provided by the facility after discharge.
CCI Rule 400.4166 D ischarge plan.
(1) When a resident is discharged from institutional
care, all of the following information shall be
documented in the case record within 14 days after
discharge:
(e) A statement that the discharge plan
recommendations, including medical and dental follow
up that is needed, have been reviewed with the
resident and with the parent and with the responsible
case manager.
One of one closed case file reviewed failed to include a statement that the
discharge plan recommendations, including medical and dental follow up that is
needed, have been reviewed with the youth and with the parent and with the
responsible case manager.
CCI Rule 400.4125 Personal possessions; money; clothing; storage
space.
(1) A licensee shall have a written policy that
designates all of the following:
(b) The method used to accurately account for and
return possessions and money to the resident or
guardian upon discharge.
Two of two youth case files reviewed failed to include documentation of the method
used to accurately account for and return possessions and money to the youth or
g uardian upon discharge.
CCI Rule 400.4152 Initial documentation.
At the time of admission, all of the following shall be in
the resident’s case record:
(c) A brief description of the resident’s preparation for
placement and general physical and emotional state at
the time of admission.

Two of two youth case files reviewed failed to document a brief description of the
youth’s preparation for placement and general physical and emotional state at the
t ime of admission.
CCI Rule 400.4152 Initial documentation.
At the time of admission, all of the following shall be in
the resident’s case record:
(i) Documentation that the grievance policy was
provided as required in R 400.4132.
Two of two youth case files reviewed failed to document that the grievance policy
w as provided at the time of admission.
CCI Rule 400.4155 Institutions not detention institutions or shelter
care institutions; initial treatment plan.
(3) The initial treatment plan shall include all of the
following:
(d) Indicators of goal achievement.
Two of two youth case reviewed did not include documentation of indicators of goal
a chievement.
CCI Rule 400.4155 Institutions not detention institutions or shelter
care institutions; initial treatment plan.
(3) The initial treatment plan shall include all of the
following:
(e) The person responsible for coordinating and
implementing the resident and family treatment goals.
Two of two youth case files reviewed failed to document the person responsible for
coordinating and implementing the youth and family treatment goals within the
i nitial treatment plan.
CCI Rule 400.4155 Institutions not detention institutions or shelter
care institutions; initial treatment plan.
(4) The social service worker shall sign and date the
initial treatment plan.
Two of two youth case files reviewed did not have direct care worker signatures on
i nitial treatment plan.

CCI Rule 400.4155 Institutions not detention institutions or shelter
care institutions; initial treatment plan.
(5) The social service supervisor shall approve,
countersign, and date the initial treatment plan.
Two of two youth case reviewed did not have supervisory signatures on initial
treatment plan.
IV. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
The agency was offered technical assistance in the following areas:
• Technical assistance was provided to the agency in the area of licensing rule
R400.4152 (1)(a) and contract item RFCAN 2.10. When reviewing case
records for compliance relative to initial documentation, it was found that the
agency did not have a consistent manner of capturing the required information,
nor was there consistency when reviewing case files for the information. The
lack of consistency also made it challenging for staff to retrieve documentation
to provide it for review. A sample of a regulation-based intake document was
shared with the agency for review and inspiration.
• Technical assistance was provided relative to the process and forms utilized to
assess the needs and strengths of youth in the program. The RFCAN contract
requires the use of specified tools and after being awarded the contract the
agency experienced some difficulty in accessing the system. The agency was
provided with information that will assist in contacting the help desk to
troubleshoot issues accessing the system. The agency was also reminded
about the importance of knowledge of the terms and expectations of the
contract for overall compliance.
V. CONSULTATION
The agency was offered consultation in the following areas:
• The agency was provided consultation regarding licensing rule R400.4167(4) -
Case Records. Agency was provided some consultation regarding the
requirement and benefit of proper maintenance of case records. Case records
that were reviewed were being maintained in a manner that did not allow for
easy review of documents, nor did it allow for agency staff to quickly locate and
provide documents for review.
VI. EVALUATION OF RENEWAL PERIOD
Maltreatment in Care
There were no substantiated incidents of maltreatment in care during this licensing
period.

Corrective Action Plan Compliance
The agency has not been required to submit any corrective action plans during this
period under review.
Financial Overview
An overview of the financial documents for Mission Point was completed. No
concerns were noted. As this is the original review, it has only been six months
and the agency is not yet due for an annual financial audit.
PREA compliance (if applicable)
N/A
Chief Administrator Assessment
The Chief Administrator Assessment was completed and submitted for review. The
assessment documented that the agency has been in compliance during its 6-
month original status. No areas of concern were noted. The facility has been
successful in obtaining a RFCAN contract during this review period. The
assessment also indicated an appropriate plan for continued monitoring of
compliance.
Staff and Youth Interviews
Two staff, one supervisor and two administrators were interviewed during the
assessment. No concerns were noted, and the employees provided positive
feedback regarding the company and its services in the community. The
administrative staff have expressed their desire to continue working with the
Division of Child Welfare Licensing and the Department of Health and Human
Services for improved outcomes for those serviced by the facility.
The facility currently has placement of two youth in the program. Both youths were
interviewed for the audit. One youth reported to be doing very well in the program
and feels that the structure of the program along with the encouragement of the
staff has been very beneficial for her. The second youth reported not feeling as if
the program was beneficial and admits to struggling to remain. Youth has
AWOLed before but was safely returned to the facility. The concerns and the
struggles of the youth were appropriately shared with the facility.
Description of Agency Walk Through
A walk through was completed. The agency was found to be well maintained and
appropriately staffed.
VII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the agency is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it is
recommended that the agency will be issued a renewal of their regular license.
